title: 111_s788
content: The "m-SPAM Act of 2009" is cited as the short title of the Act. Certain qualifying messages are exempted from the definition of mobile service commercial message. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 is amended to define "mobile service commercial message" as a commercial electronic mail message sent to a wireless device used by a subscriber of commercial mobile service. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 defines a "mobile service commercial message" as a message sent to a wireless device without prior agreement, excluding messages related to commercial transactions or providing information like warranties or product recalls. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 requires commercial messages to provide security information and notice of changes in ongoing commercial relationships. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 mandates that commercial messages must include security information and notifications of changes in ongoing commercial relationships, such as account balance updates or statements. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 requires commercial messages to include information related to employment relationships or benefit plans, as well as deliver goods or services that the recipient is entitled to under a previous transaction agreement. The term "short message" refers to a text or message sent to a wireless device. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 allows the sending of short messages between wireless devices and mobile service commercial messages without charge to subscribers. The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 permits commercial mobile service providers to send free commercial messages to subscribers unless they opt out. Amendments include changes to section 14(b) regarding considerations for providers of commercial mobile service. SEC. 3. PROHIBITION ON UNAUTHORIZED MOBILE SERVICE COMMERCIAL MESSAGES CONTAINING UNSOLICITED ADVERTISEMENTS. Section 227(b)(1) of the Communications Act of 1934 is amended to prohibit sending mobile service commercial messages without prior authorization. The amendment to Section 227(d) of the Communications Act of 1934 clarifies the applicability of the prohibition on mobile service commercial messages, allowing for the sending of short messages between wireless devices or from a commercial mobile service provider to its subscribers at no cost. The amendment clarifies that commercial mobile service providers can send messages to subscribers at no charge unless the subscriber opts out. It also specifies that states do not have greater authority over mobile service commercial messages than they do over commercial electronic mail messages under the CAN-SPAM Act of 2003. Mobile service commercial messages containing unsolicited advertisements sent to cellular telephones explicitly prohibited. The Federal Trade Commission will revise the do-not-call registry provisions to prohibit sending unsolicited mobile service commercial messages to numbers listed on the registry, except for messages sent by the mobile service provider to its subscribers at no cost. The term "mobile service commercial message" is defined in the CAN-SPAM Act of 2003, while "commercial mobile service" is defined in the Communications Act of 1934.
